content:
her forms. Suppose a neighbor tells a parent, “The local
public  schools  are  so  bad  that  you  ought  to  send  your  kids  to  private
school,” and the parent responds, “Do you think I’m rich?” The point of
this rhetorical question is that it is absurd to think that the parent is rich,
presumably because of her lifestyle or house, which the neighbor can easily
see. Without being rich, the parent cannot afford a private school, so the
neighbor’s advice is useless.
